Vol. XXXV, No. 21 Complimentary to homes by request ONLINE: WWW.SPENCERNEWLEADER.COM Friday, June 3, 2011 Through the rain, Memorial Day shines Elisa Krochmalnyckyj photo EAST BROOKFIELD — East Brookfield Police Officer Joseph Lazarick salutes at the Memorial Day Parade. David Dore photo NORTH BROOKFIELD — Owen Snyder, 2, of Lunenburg waves a couple of flags before the North Brookfield Memorial Day events. His grandfather is James Foyle, the organizer of the annual observance. Rain showers on Monday, May 30, caused some Memorial Day plans to be shifted in Spencer, Leicester and the Brookfields, but that didn’t stop residents from coming out and honoring local veterans in a plethora of ceremonies. More photos in the page B Section. David Dore photo WEST BROOKFIELD — Members of the William Diamond Junior Fife and Drum Corps, based in Lexington, practice before the parade. David Dore photo LEICESTER — Kenneth Desautels, center, and his sons, Dean, left, and Keith, right, were part of the color guard for Leicester’s parade. They are all military veterans: Kenneth from Vietnam, Dean from Afghanistan and Keith from Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm. Farewell to O’Brien, the second time around BY DAVID DORE NEW LEADER STAFF WRITER NORTH BROOKFIELD — Claiming it would prevent teacher layoffs and the elimination of music, art and sports, School Committee Chairman Brent Hildick urged selectmen last week to present voters with a $460,000 Proposition 2 1/2 override in a couple of weeks. BY DAVID DORE NEW LEADER STAFF WRITER LEICESTER — Mary O’Brien had been the Leicester Senior Center outreach coordinator for about a decade when she decided in October 2003 it was time to retire. But not everyone in town agreed with her. “They had a petition around to bring me back,” said O’Brien. David Dore photos Mary O’Brien stands with granddaughter Kate Cotillo, 10, of Northborough at her retirement party Thursday, May 26 at the Leicester Senior Center. However, selectmen said they wanted to see how negotiations with the teachers’ union on health insurance and wage concessions went first before making a decision. That decision could come as soon as Tuesday, May 31 — after the Spencer New Leader’s press deadline. According to Hildick, the school district is facing a “That was dress rehearsal, I guess.” “I didn’t start it, but I did support it,” said Janice Nowicki, the Senior Center director at the time. O’Brien changed her mind and stayed on for another eight years. On Thursday, May 26, the Senior Center marked her retirement for the second time. It was her final day of work, except for some appointments this week. “This day is bittersweet for me,” O’Brien told the family, friends and dignitaries who gathered for her retirement party. “As you might Turn To O’BRIEN page A16 $460K override sought for North Brookfield schools Brent Hildick $460,464 deficit in next year’s $6.47 million budget. The spending plan approved by the School Committee is a 5.4 percent increase from this year, and does not include health insurance costs included in the town budget. Hildick said Tuesday, May 24 the School Committee Turn To OVERRIDE page A15 Civil War coming to West Brookfield common BY ELISA KROCHMALNYCKYJ NEW LEADER CORRESPONDENT WEST BROOKFIELD — Imagine stepping out your front door and right into the Civil War. Imagine no more. Just head to the West Brookfield Town Common on Saturday, June 4 for a Civil War living history encampment. “It will interest a lot of people,” said Nancy Parker, of the West Brookfield Historical Commission. “We’re hoping the events and features will bring people in. It’s for everybody.” Event-goers will see a true depiction of a Union camp, a witness to how the soldiers lived, what they ate, where they slept and what hardships they endured. A horse-drawn covered wagon will also be on hand to give rides to guests. There will also be Union military drills, a rifle-firing demonstration and other re-enactments, including detained Confederate soldiers. All soldiers will wear authentic war regalia. “They have to perform just like if they’d been in the Civil War,” Parker said. “When they are there, they live like they are in the war. They just do so much.” Doing the reenacting will be the 15th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry Re-enactors. The re-enactors will be portraying soldiers in the 15th Volunteer Infantry, which, back 150 years ago, was the Civil War company that comprised members of the Brookfields. “They were one of the top fighting regiments in the Civil War, and in all the major battles,” Parker said. The event will be held from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Town Common, routes 9 and 67. The rain date is Sunday, June 5. One of the biggest benefits is that visitors are invited to chat with those in the encampment, who have a wealth of knowledge, Turn To CIVIL WAR page A15
